title: tobar an dualchais what can proverbs tell us about
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineIn recent years, interest in this concept has been growing exponentially, with a iety of groups recognising its importance as a sense of place and belonging or identying it as the rootedness us modern people are understandably desperate for. which Edward Dwelly noted in his dictionary.The Place of one#s birth.Heredity, native or hereditary temper, spirit or blood.Visage, countenance.Hereditary right. could be one of the cornerstones of a reconstructed Gaelic worldview. The identity of a person could undoubtedly be forged by the place of their birth and the community of that place, particularly at a time in the past when populations were less mobile.The traits of a person’s parents manest in their physical appearance their spirit, likes and dislikes, and sometimes even interests or inclinations might appear hereditary – not just from mother and father but perhaps from an ancestor remembered only by name and special characteristic, like poesy or craft skill..The failure by clan chiefs and other landed gentry to recognise this customary right held by the people since time immemorial underpins the Clearances, while demands for its recognition echo through much of the collective action undertaken against this violence, trauma, and dispossession. as far back in history as I can.The world and society these people lived in was so dferent to ours today, making context crucial to understanding the words being used and the philosophy from which they derive.Aside from the multitude which are in still in use today, there are published proverb collections as well as countless sound recordings, many digitized and made easily accessible by Tobar an Dualchais.By their nature proverbs cut across boundaries of class and gender, their survival relying upon oral transmission, on being commonly known in a community and thus reflecting its values. They are that memorable phrase we hear our elders say once they have explained its meaning to us, we are unlikely to forget it.Theyto us often and roll off the tongue.One of the most important collections of Gaelic proverbs was published in  by Alexander Nicolson .However, Nicolson was merely re-printing a collection made by Donald Macintosh, a Perthshire-born clergyman, first printed in Edinburgh in . Nicolson called the collection “a genuine product of the past” with Macintosh merely acting as collator and translator. of Islay, perhaps coined in the times when the MacLeans, MacDonalds, and later Campbells feuded over the island the second one is a rhyme about the MacAlpines, their former seat in Dunstaffnage, and their ancient claim to the throne of Scotland:When the natives forsake Islay, farewell the peace of Scotland!Children of the native kings, Who reigned down at Dunstaffnage, Who first the crown of Alba owned, And still have native claim to it..It also tells us that there are always grave, far-reaching political consequences whenever an indigenous population is forced to abandon its home.as a hereditary right can last for centuries. The strength of attachment to people and place shines through both.Blood is stronger than breeding., ‘blood is thicker than water’, and perhaps it should come as no surprise to us that a society which places strong emphasis on ancestry and blood ties should have so many proverbs reinforcing such beliefs..Sad is the inheritance of a bad disease.This proverb is the perfect reminder that not everything we inherit from our ancestors is good. Psychologically and spiritually, we inherit their trauma physically, as the proverb reminds us, we may inherit their medical conditions.By accepting the full extent of our inheritance – strength and weakness, the beautul and the ugly – we grow closer to our ancestors and empower ourselves to heal from what they could not.has always been characterised by plurality and complexity, reflecting the complex Gàidhealtachd to which it belonged.For centuries, fostering children has been an important feature of Gaelic society, and for all the influence that DNA can have on us, the nurture we receive during our formative years has just as much –not more – influence on who we become within our community.In a changing world, it is inspiring to see people across the Gàidhealtachd connecting with the cultural ‘mycelium’ of their place and rooting themselves in it, whether it is their ancestral homeland or adoptive home.can be a wellspring of transformative energy for place-based revitalisation.Sometimes it seems to burst like lightning, explosively cleaving through adversity. But it is also the stream – the carrying stream – slowly weathering stone, flowing ever on from generation to generation.

title: three local groups combine for ecos park clean up effort
story: Three local groups combining their efforts at Ecos Nature Park at the weekend to make the area more welcoming for people from the local community, visitors and tourists.Ecos parkrun, Ballymena Runners and the Friends of Ecos are all regular visitors to the park, and have a shared interest in the upkeep of it for the benefit of everyone.The three groups got together to plant oak trees to celebrate the th anniversary of Ecos parkrun,and to do a litter pick around the paths and parking areas.Susanna Allen, Event Director for Ecos parkrun, said: “This month we celebrate  years of Ecos parkrun, so it was important to us to mark the occasion. We were delighted to work with Friends of Ecos and Ballymena Runners to plant  oak trees, one for each year of the parkrun.“We also worked together to complete a litter pick which benefits everyone who uses the park, and leaves it litter free and tidy for our th anniversary run on th March. Parkrun tourism is thriving and over the past  years, , people from over  running clubs from across the UK and Ireland have come to visit Ecos parkrun.”Susanna also paid tribute to the hundreds of volunteers who help out, adding: “I’d like to thank all the volunteers at the parkrun and everyone who helped with the litter pick today.”Alex Scullion, chair of Friends of Ecos, said: Friends of Ecos are very happy to be involved in assisting in any venture which increases the ecology and bioersity in the park,and are especially keen to be involved in the celebration of the th anniversary of Ecos parkrun.Alastair Donaghy, chair of Ballymena Runners, commented: “Many of our  club members take part in the Ecos parkrun every week, and many of our club runs take place in and around the park. We are delighted to be playing our part by helping make Ecos a tidy and pleasant place for everyone in the community to enjoy.”Over  people took part in the activities and collected more than a dozen bags of litter.The Ecos parkrun th anniversary parkrun will take place on Saturday th March with group warm up at .am and the presentation of the Ecos spirit of parkrun award. Susanna added: “We would encourage people to join us at parkrun to run, jog or walk with us. ”Information on the events and how to join in are on the Ecos parkrun and Ballymena Runners websites and facebook pages.

title: wwwballymenaguardiancouknews20220324newspcr testing to come to an end for most people from next month
story: Testing will continue to play a vital role in Northern Ireland’s response to the COVID- pandemic over the coming months, Health Minister Robin Swann has emphasised. The Minister announced that a more targeted approach to testing will be introduced on a phased basis from next month, with the focus on supporting and protecting those at highest risk of serious illness. Testing will continue to be available for those eligible for COVID- treatments. Under the new policy, PCR testing will cease for most people with symptoms from  April - however free lateral flow tests will continue to be available to the public to use should they develop symptoms of COVID-. Lateral flow tests will also continue to be available free of charge to support those living in, working in or visiting a higher risk setting such as a care home until the end of June, with further review then. The policy covers testing and contact tracing and takes effect from  April. No changes will be introduced until that date. The policy will be kept under review during the period of transition up until the end of June. The Health Minister stated: “The new policy reflects the new realities of the pandemic. While the prevalence of the virus remains at a high level, the risk of serious illness has been signicantly reduced - thanks in no small measure to our vaccination programme and the use of innovative COVID- treatments. “The risk posed by the virus at the present time does not justy testing and isolating large swathes of the population at the levels that we have seen to date in the past two years. Test and trace will continue to have a key role and will be used in a more focused and targeted way to support and protect our most vulnerable. This will be kept under very close review and we will have contingency plans in place so that we can scale up should it be required.” A range of changes will take effect from the  April: PCR testing will no longer be recommended or available for most people with symptoms. It will still be available to support the small group for whom it is recommended for clinical reasons. The PCR home ordering service will remain available for the general public to support those for whom PCR is recommended.Publicly accessible COVID- testing sites will close. Local Health and Social Care Trusts will continue to provide PCR testing to support clinical care.Those with symptoms will be advised to use lateral flow devicesto test instead of booking a PCR. This will be kept under review and could remain in place up to the end of June depending on disease trajectory.Routine asymptomatic testingwill continue to be advised for those living, working and visiting health and social care settings including hospitals and care homes and other high risk settings in line with public health advice. This will be kept under review.Asymptomatic LFD testing for the wider population will cease. Access to free LFDs for this purpose will cease.Routine asymptomatic workplace testing will cease.Routine asymptomatic testing in most educational settingswill cease at the Easter break.Asymptomatic testing in special schools will continue after Easter and will be kept under review. It may continue until the end of June .Routine population contact tracing will be phased out between mid-April and the end of June.  Chief Medical Officer Professor Sir Michael McBride said: “We will continue throughout the transition phase to support and protect our most vulnerable. After these changes are introduced from  April, I would urge people to check on NI Directtesting remains recommended for them - for examplethey are eligible for new treatments. In the coming weeks, the Department will also be working to provide advice and support to those eligible for treatments. It is particularly important that those who are at higher risk of serious illness follow the guidance on getting tested.” The Chief Medical Officer added: “The tools at our disposal to protect people who are at higher risk from COVID- have advanced considerably since the early days of the pandemic. Alongside the vaccine and booster programme, new COVID- treatments continue to be used by patients in Northern Ireland and new treatments are in development. “As the amount of testing across society reduces, our behaviour and actions have an even more important role in preventing transmission and keeping others safe. I urge everyone to continue to follow the public health guidance including continuing to wear a face covering in enclosed settings like public transport and when visiting hospitals and care homes.” The changes do not take effect until  April, and current testing provision will continue until then. Please keep following the latest public health advice as set out on NI Direct.

title: the doctors couldnt believe daddy was going into icu because he was doing so well
story: Maureen McPartland spoke of her devastation over not being able to hold a funeral for her father, Tony MitchellExpand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseTony Mitchell passed away three weeks after testing positive for Covid. FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueTony Mitchell passed away three weeks after testing positive for Covid.Ralph HewittTwitterEmailMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailTONY MITCHELLpassed away at Craigavon Area Hospital, Co Armagh, on April , , after testing positive for Covid- three weeks earlier.“Daddy caught it at the start of the pandemic and was very unlucky,” said his daughter Maureen McParland . “If he had caught it now he would have been fine, as we’ve been told.“Everything has changed and people with Covid have had funerals and wakes, and everything that goes with the passing of loved one, whereas we have not.“Our family is trying to come to terms with that. When you hear about Boris Johnson partying four weeks after daddy had died, I just didn#t believe it.”Mr Mitchell made a living by travelling the country to carry out building work. His daughter said he was an “all-rounder” and could put his hand to anything.He was also a successful darts player in the s and competed against famous players such as Bobby George, John Lowe and Jocky Wilson.“My daddy worked right up to the day he went into hospital,” said Ms McParland. “He was fit and healthy. The doctors couldn#t believe that he was going into ICU because he was doing so well.“People think you have to be old or have underlying conditions but it doesn#t matter, the virus still took them.“It’s just very, very unfair. We do all need to get back to normal but we just need to be careful.”Mr Mitchell is survived by daughters Ann, Celia, Philomena and Maureen. title: when the ambulance drove off little did we know there would be no contact with her again
story: When Jemima George died from Covid, her daughter Roberta could not attend the funeral as she too was battling the virusExpand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseJemima George is fondly remembered as the heart and soul of her family FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueJemima George is fondly remembered as the heart and soul of her familyLisa SmythTwitterMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailJEMIMA George was the heart and soul of her family.Covid- robbed them of a beloved great grandmother. It even snatched away their chance to say a proper goodbye to her.The depth of her family’s grief made headlines earlier this year. Her son-in-law, DUP MP Jim Shannon, challenged Boris Johnson over the lockdown parties at  Downing Street which took place at the same time Ms George , from Newtownards, Co Down, lost her le to the virus in October .“She was so devoted to her family, she lived for her family,” said Mr Shannon.“Birthdays, anniversaries, she never forgot any of them. Christmas was particularly special, and even though she and my father-in-law Robert were pensioners, all their savings would go to the family.“She would have saved up all her coppers, silvers and pounds in a jar and there would be money for everyone at Christmas.Ms George was moved from the emergency department at the Ulster Hospital on the outskirts of east Belfast to a ward where her daughter, Roberta, was also being treated for Covid.Mr Shannon continued: “Roberta couldn’t even go and see her mum even though they were in the same ward.“She was admitted to the hospital on Monday and died on Friday.“It was the horrible and cruel way that she was taken away from us [that hurt so much]. When the ambulance drove off, little did we know there would be no contact with her again.“Roberta couldn’t even go to the funeral because she was still in hospital fighting for her le.“Sandra was left to organise everything because Roberta was so sick. story: The semi-permanent installations mean some personnel can work from home on laptops while others work from council buildings.Getty ImagesTom Smith FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueThe semi-permanent installations mean some personnel can work from home on laptops while others work from council buildings.Michael KenwoodMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailA council has been criticised for agreeing to spend £, on “fancy cameras” for people who like “Zooming in and out” of remote meetings.Despite objections, Ards and North Down Council is to spend £, to support two semi-permanent installations – one in Bangor Chamber and one in Ards Chamber for “hybrid” council and committee meetings.It means some personnel can work from home on laptops while others work from council buildings. It also means the public and press can continue to watch meetings live online.Independent unionist Tom Smith was one of three against the proposal, stating it was “ridiculous” to spend £, of ratepayers’ money on “fancy cameras”. Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Read MoreWe live in fear, says mother of boy attacked ‘for being Protestant’Stormont department criticised for building Derry park-and-ride which breaches planning rulesHe said: “The Health Minister felt it was safe enough to remove the legal restrictions, and guidance is guidance. Members of the public are free to ignore guidance and make their own decisions.“It has always been my position that once regulations are removed we should move back to meeting in public. I think there are some sections of the public sector who are too comfortable and don’t want to go back. They like Zooming in and out. That’s fine for them, but for us the best place to do business is in person across the chamber.“The cost is unacceptable. If you want to reach the public, do a live audio stream, which would reduce the costs. All of our meetings are recorded anywayyou want to listen back. So we don’t need a plethora of video cameras looking down our throats, just so we can get close ups during the meetings.”DUP councillor Stephen McIlveen noted that some councillors and staff “are vulnerable, and we shouldn’t be using ourselves merely as examples. We should be taking consideration of other people”.“Where some members may feel comfortable going into public meetings, I know there are some who are very reluctant, and they will force themselves to do it. But we shouldn’t be in a position where we are forcing potentially vulnerable people into potentially dangerous situations,” he said.“Similarly we should not be potentially excluding people from meetings, who don’t feel comfortable enough to attend. I think we should be looking at something that is a bit more flexible.”​​​​​​​​​​​​​​The DUP, Alliance, the UUP and one Independent councillor supported the council officer’s recommendation for the plan, while one TUV elected representative and two independent unionists voted against it.Related topicsUlster Unionist PartyAlliance PartyTraditional Unionist VoiceMost ReadNorth Belfast residents shocked by sudden collapse of wall of Chinese takeaway: ‘It could have been fatal’Outrage as schoolboyis victim of ‘sectarian attack’ in north BelfastMum of Belfast man Joseph Ritch pays tribute to her ‘lovely boy’ who died following assault in ArdoyneSinn Fein MLA Emma Rogan absent for almost  committee meetingsWe live in fear, says mother of boy attacked ‘for being Protestant’Top VideosPlayVideo: Wall collapses in north Belfast"data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph incoming be .ece AUTOCROP wh bt_KS_.jpg w,https:www.belfasttelegraph incoming be .ece AUTOCROP wh bt_KS_.jpg w" data-sizes"auto"  "PlayCharles and Camilla visit CS Lewis Square in east Belfast PlayVideo: Heartbroken mother releases footage of moment her son died in a fireball motorcycle crash - Credit: Colm O’ReillySam McBrideTwitterEmailMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailAfter being asked five times for a copy of a civil servant’s register of interests, a Stormont department has refused to allow the public to see it — claiming that it cannot release the information because of a court case.Six months ago, an employment tribunal unanimously found that Tamara Bronckaers, a senior vet at the Department of Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairswith an “exemplary performance and record”, had been treated appallingly and effectively sacked because she blew the whistle on potential fraud and animal suffering.Despite the Executive’s repeated pledges of transparency, the department has been unusually reluctant to respond to requests for even basic details in relation to the case. DAERA is now using taxpayers’ money to attempt to overturn the devastating employment tribunal judgment that raised serious concerns about Northern Ireland’s chief vet and one of his deputies — but is refusing to say whether that was approved by the department’s minister, Edwin Poots.Unless the department succeeds in persuading the Court of Appeal to overturn the ruling, the public could be forced to pay £m to compensate Dr Bronckaers, along with huge legal bills.In a ,-word judgment, Employment Judge Ó Murray repeatedly criticised the whistleblower’s treatment by two of her senior colleagues — line manager Julian Henderson and chief vet Robert Huey.At the heart of the case was Dr Bronckaers’ desire to pursue enforcement action against Ballymena Livestock Market over alleged suffering caused to animals and animal movements being electronically deleted from DAERA’s much-vaunted computer system meant to track all livestock moves to ensure traceability of meat.Dr Huey told her he knew the manager of the market personally and also knew its chairman. Both he and Dr Henderson discouraged her from pursuing enforcement, with Dr Bronckaers left in tears after an encounter with Dr Huey. Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up At the end of January, the Belfastasked DAERA for a copy of Dr Huey and Dr Henderson’s declaration of interests. After multiple requests, the department eventually replied to say that because Dr Huey is a member of the departmental board his declarations were available at a page on its website.However, it did not respond in relation to Dr Henderson, a grade five senior principal veterinary officer who — according to the judgment — was heavily involved in undermining Dr Bronckaers after she attempted to enforce the law.After five requests, the department eventually responded to say: “As this is a court matter, the department will not be commenting any further.”The tribunal found as a matter of fact that Dr Huey knew the manager of Ballymena Livestock Market “personally” and that “he knew the owner of the market who was chairman of the Markets Association”. The tribunal found that Dr Huey acted in a way which discouraged Dr Bronckaers from enforcing the law against Ballymena Livestock Market.Whilst there is no suggestion that there is was any formal connection between Dr Huey and Mr Henderson and Ballymena Livestock Market, it is unclear from the judgment what Dr Huey meant when he told the tribunal that he knew the manager “personally”.There is no reference to anyone at Ballymena Livestock Market in Dr Huey’s register of interests. Credit: Zivica KerkezLisa SmythTwitterMarch   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailNorthern Ireland’s Children’s Commissioner has said she believes some primary schools are too afraid to promote the Covid- vaccine to parents.Koulla Yiasouma said she is aware of cases where staff in secondary schools endured “awful intimidation and harassment” after students were given information on the Covid- vaccine.As a result, Ms Yiasouma, who has herself received abuse for her comments on teenagers receiving the vaccine, said she does not blame any schools that do not want to become involved vaccination programme.And she also said she does not envy parents who are trying to decide whether to vaccinate their young children against the virus.It comes after it emerged that less than % of children aged between five and  in Northern Ireland have received a Covid- vaccine.In December, the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisationrecommended that the vaccine be offered to five to -year-olds deemed at particular risk from the virus and those who live with someone who is immunocompromised.Then, in February, it recommended that the programme could be extended to all children in the age group.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up However, only , doses of the vaccine have been administered to children between the ages of five and .Ms Yiasouma said: “I think there are a number of issues at play here and I’m not sure safety is the biggest concern.“The Public Health Agencyhas put quite a lot of information on the safety of the vaccines on its website, but I think it would be betterit was being made more available to parents.“There are questions over the benefits of the vaccine to children and parents might not see the point in going to the trouble of finding out more.“It’s not even as though the vaccine is being administered in the school setting, parents have to go and make an appointment themselves, yet they aren’t clear about the benefits of the vaccine.“What I’m also hearing from parents is that they aren’t sure about giving the vaccine to their child simply for the benefit of the community.“We are seeing children getting it where there is a vulnerable family member but where that isn’t the case, there is more hesitancy from parents.“I don’t envy parents having to make the decision and I wouldn’t say they should or shouldn’t.“What I would advise is that they read up all the information from the PHA and make their own decision.”The Department of Health has acknowledged the low uptake in children between the ages of five and  and said the PHA has been working with a range of organisations to increase the number of doses administered in the age group.These include the health trusts and Education Authority, however, Ms Yiasouma said schools are reticent to become involved in the delivery of the programme. She explained: “I spoke to secondary schools where staff were threatened, there was awful intimidation and harassment, which I think has made primary schools very, very reluctant to be seen promoting the vaccine.”Ms Yiasouma also said there is a perception that a younger child having to isolate after testing positive and missing a week of school is not as harmful as when it happens to teenagers preparing for exams.However, she warned that children in primary one and two have suffered substantial harm as a result of the pandemic.“They have missed out on the preparation to ensure they are ready for school and we’re seeing them coming in and they don’t have the language skills or other skills required,” she continued.“Aside from children with special educational needs, who suffered the most harm throughout the pandemic, it is those children at the start of the school career that we’re most worried about.”Rachel Spiers, Immunisation and Vaccination Programme Manager at the PHA, on Thursday night said vaccination remains “one of the most important things” parents can do to protect children against ill-health.“Evenyour child has already had Covid-, it is still important to get them vaccinated, as being fully-vaccinated can offer them the best protection from the virus and severe disease, as we have seen that it can be possible to develop Covid- more than once,” she explained.While most children aged five to  will have mild diseasethey contract Covid-, some may experience symptoms which last longer than just a few days.“Vaccination of children in this age group has been shown to help prevent the small number of hospitalisations and intensive care admissions that can occur in this age group,” said Ms Spiers“It has also been shown to help provide short-term protection against non-severe disease. “When you look at the risk of Covid- against the risk of the vaccine, it’s more beneficial for children to receive the vaccine.”Related topicsDepartment of title: security alert at peacebuilding event in north belfast with irish foreign minister simon coveney in attendance
story: An event at which Irish Foreign Affairs Minister Simon Coveney is a guest speaker has been evacuated in Belfast due to a security alert.Sources say a van was hijacked on the Shankill, a canister placed on board and the driver forced to drive it to Holy Cross Church. Police are understood to be putting a  metre exclusion zone in place.Tim Attwood, who was moderating the event, said it was “very unfortunate that the event has been cancelled and more importantly the disruption to local community.“The message of the minister in the short time he was speaking and of the John and Pat Hume Foundation is that you can only achieve your goals through peaceful and nonviolent means,” he continued.Security alert latest, Sources saying a van was hijacked on the Shankill Road, a cannister placed on board and the driver forced to drive it to Holy Cross church, the driver said to be very distressed the event organised by the John and Pat Hume Foundation has been abandoned.— Allison MorrisMarch , “Those who think they can drag us back to those dark days are very much mistaken, they are long gone and this will only renew our efforts for peace and reconciliation and our work will continue.”PSNI officers are currently in attendance at the security alert at the Crumlin Road area of north Belfast.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Motorists are advised to avoid the area and seek alternative main routes for their journey.Mr Coveney was giving an address as part of the Time to Build The Common Ground. He has since tweeted: “In Belfast with @Humefoundation to honour John  Pat’s legacy of peace for all communities.Saddened  frustrated that someone has been attacked  victimised in this way and my thoughts are with him  his family. My thanks to ⁦@PoliceServiceNI.”In Belfast with @Humefoundation to honour John  Pat’s legacy of peace for all communities. story: Ireland’s Foreign Affairs Minister Simon Coveney was speaking at the event when it was halted  FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueIreland’s Foreign Affairs Minister Simon Coveney was speaking at the event when it was halted By Dominic McGrath, PAMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailA security alert in Belfast has caused the cancellation of a peacebuilding event attended by the Irish Foreign Affairs Minister.Simon Coveney was speaking at the event organised by the John and Pat Hume Foundation in Belfast when he abruptly ended his speech and was ushered from the room.The Houben Centre, on the Crumlin Road, has been evacuated.Mr Coveney had been speaking about the importance of reconciliation in Northern Ireland.He had told the event: “The patient work of reconciliation and deepening of relationships does need to continue on our own island.”Police are currently in attendance of a security alert at the Crumlin Road area of North Belfast this morning .Motorists are advised to avoid the area and seek alternative main routes for their journey. pic pikqdUNM— Police North BelfastMarch , A spokesperson for Mr Coveney said: “The minister and team are safe, have been taken to a secure location and the PSNI are doing their work.”Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Tim Attwood, from the Foundation, told the PA news agency that the security alert is a reminder “to everyone that there is no role in our society for violence”.He added: “A suspect device will not stop the work of the John and Pat Hume Foundation.”A van was hijacked as part of the incident, according to North Belfast Sinn Fein MP John Finucane.The attack on an event involving Minister Simon Coveney at North Belfast’s Houben Centre today is disgraceful.Those behind the van hijacking which was left on church grounds have no place in society.While they try to bring back the past, we will keep working for the future. pic UtpILDs— John Finucane MPMarch , He tweeted: “The attack on an event involving Minister Simon Coveney at North Belfast’s Houben Centre today is disgraceful.“Those behind the van hijacking which was left on church grounds have no place in society.“While they try to bring back the past, we will keep working for the future.”In a statement, a PSNI spokesperson said: “Police are currently in attendance of a security alert at the Crumlin Road area of north Belfast.Worrying situation in Belfast BreenTwitterEmailMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailA Sinn Fein MLA hasn’t spoken in the Assembly nor attended two committees on which she sits for over a year.Emma Rogan, who represents South Down, has missed  meetings of the Justice Committee and  meetings of the Audit Committee.According to records, she has not spoken in the Assembly in almost  months.  Sinn Fein has not responded to requests for comment.Ms Rogan, whose father was killed in the UVF’s  Loughinisland Massacre, was deselected by the party last May.Read MoreNorthern Ireland set for #problems and confusion# over a clash between UK and EU law, Government admitsLoyalist paramilitaries couldn’t back ceasefires now: PUPCathy Mason, who sits on Newry, Mourne and Down District Council, was chosen ahead of her following a selection convention.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Ms Roganhad been co-opted into the Assembly in  to replace Chris Hazzard after he was elected South Down MP.  She gave up a good job in banking to take up the position for the party. Ms Rogan still describes herself as “Sinn Fein MLA for South Down” in her Twitter biography.She has not attended a meeting of the Justice Committee since  February .The minutes of dozens of meetings she has missed record apologies for not being present.She has not attended a meeting of the Audit Committee since  February .The parliamentary monitoring website TheyWorkForYou records her as having last spoken in the Assembly on  February .Ms Rogan has continued to vote by proxy but her absence in Parliament Buildings has raised eyebrows across parties.The Sinn Fein MLA was just a schoolgirl when her father Adrian  was killed along with five others in Loughinisland.Two UVF gunmen opened fire in a pub in the village pub where locals had gathered to watch the Republic of Ireland’s football team take on Italy in the  World Cup.Ms Rogan is a prominent member of the Loughinisland Justice Group which has been battling to uncover the truth behind the attack on the Heights Bars.It is understood she was approached by Sinn Fein to be co-opted into the Assembly five years ago. Speaking at the time, she said she was “thrilled” to be an MLA.“Sinn Féin is growing from strength to strength and people in our constituency can feel reassured that we will represent them when they need help. We can provide strong representation,” she said.Councillor Mason, who was selected ahead of Ms Rogan, will join sitting MLA Sinead Ennis on the party ticket.Ms Ennis apologised in January after a series of historical derogatory tweets she had written were publicised.She had made crude remarks about women and Protestants. In a tweet from , she wrote: “Those hun b*****s can kiss my arsethey think they are ruining my day out.”She had also tweeted that year: “There’s a fella by the pool here an swear to f*** he’s got bigger tits than me.”The following year she tweeted about the Rose of Tralee contest: “Oh f*** me! title: stormont department criticised for building derry park and ride which breaches planning rules
story: Anglers accuse minister of failure to admit mistakesExpand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseExtreme weather: Workmen removing cars from the River Faughan after flooding in . Credit: Kelvin Boyes Presseye FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueExtreme weather: Workmen removing cars from the River Faughan after flooding in . Credit: Kelvin Boyes PresseyeGarrett HarganTwitterEmailMarch   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailThe Department for Infrastructurehas been strongly criticised for building a second park-and-ride facility on the outskirts of Londonderry in breach of planning conditions.The River Faughan Anglersgroup spoke out after Stormont’s Public AccountsCommittee said in a scathing report that it was “alarmed and appalled” at the abysmal performance of, and lack of transparency in, the planning system.In August , the DfI park-and-ride facility beside the A bridge over the River Faughan was damaged by flooding. Cars were swept into the river and people were rescued from the rising waters.It was then discovered it was operating without planning permission or environmental assessments.Read MoreWe live in fear, says mother of boy attacked ‘for being Protestant’Council rapped for spending £k on ‘fancy cameras’ for zoom meetingsThis was because what permission it had was temporary, and a condition required the facility’s removal and the restoration of the site by , a full year before the flooding struck. Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up In effect, DfI was breaching its planning permission.While the site is no longer operational, RFA said the department is still in breach because the facility was meant to be removed and the site restored by .In , DfI submitted an application for a new park-and-ride facility that opened on the edge of Drumahoe in August last year.RFA believes this facility should be rendered “unauthorised” because it is in breach of a planning condition which required it to submit additional environmental information to the planning authority and to have this agreed before any works commenced.RFA director Dean Blackwood said the department charged with upholding the integrity and credibility of the planning system continued to demonstrate why citizens had absolutely no trust in its ability to do so.“Expert consultees such as the Northern Ireland Environment Agencyand Shared Environmental Services, whose input into environmental planning matters is essential, both declined to provide that input because of the department’s unauthorised actions, which rendered the planning condition meaningless and ineffective,” he added.“While the department might seek to play down its unauthorised actions by claiming its dedicated environmental team was on site and did not raise any concern, that is contradicted by the fact that during construction works, RFA filmed an pollution incident on the Faughan on August , , coming from works associated with the park-and-ride.”Mr Blackwood also claimed it had proved dficult to get answers or an acknowledgement of mistakes. “That it took nine Assembly questions from Rachel Woods MLA, tabled over a period of more than a year, to elicit an admission from the minister that her department did, in fact, start work in breach of its planning condition, suggests to me that the public service principles of openness and transparency hold little value in this department,” he said.The DfI accepted it had powers and s that enabled it to monitor the operation of planning matters and to oversee and secure the implementation of regional policy and good practices.However, it claimed that the responsibility to do so ultimately rested with councils, and it did not want to interfere.Compliance with any planning application is the responsibility of the relevant council, the DfI also claimed.A spokesperson said the department did not take a decision to “intentionally commence works” before the required environmental information was agreed by the council.“The facility has been operational since July . In addition, the NIEA, along with the department’s consulting advisors and dedicated environmental team, were on site extensively during construction,” they added. “During this period, they did not raise any concern or issues relating to either the environmental controls or working methods adopted.”The local council confirmed it was aware of an alleged breach of conditions. A spokeswoman said: “A report of an alleged pollution incident was received. The council engaged with the DfI, the Department for Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairs and NIEA officials on the matter.”Related topicsDepartment for InfrastructureNorthern Ireland AssemblyRachel WoodsDepartment of Agriculture, Environment  Rural Affairs - FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueSDLP’s Pat Catney joins in the celebrations singing along with campaigners, friends and family after Period Poverty Bill passes on Thursday .March   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailDon’t put off until tomorrow what you can do today.It’s a motto on getting things done, striking when the iron’s hot, being proactive rather than reactive. There are a number of slogans.Anyone who has been following the frantic goings-on in the Assembly can only assume our MLAs have finally heard them. Either that or there’s an election coming up. You decide.Then again, considering what’s being done today, could it not have been done yesterday Looking at the raft of bills flowing through the chamber these past few weeks, particularly related to education, perhaps MLAs have adopted the trait of the typical student. Last-minute cramming ahead of the summer exams.With the Assembly about to wrap up its current mandate, and elections due on May , a new to-do list will emerge. Whether a great big tick can be placed beside what needs to be done, depending on whether an Executive can get up and running, is unknown, butpast experience is anything to go by, in five years there’ll be another rush of last-minute legislation.There was a to-do list five years ago. Yes, Covid will have curtailed progress on some major issues, but the reality is that MLAs have had five years of scratching their Private Members# Bills.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up You do wonder where the urgency was in . Did the itching start so suddenly at the beginning of  Instead, there has been an extensive list of bills being rushed through, some under accelerated passage which, of course, would not have been needed had the process started earlier in the mandate. And rushed legislation isn’t always for the best. Some things need y consideration.Perhaps the biggest, and certainly the most contested, was the Integrated Education Bill from Alliance MLA Kellie Armstrong, which took six years of work to get to the Assembly.But in the last few weeks there has been the Flexible School Starting Age Bill, a bill to introduce CPR training as a formal part of the NI curriculum which was finally adopted as a ministerial directive, a bill on providing period products, a bill on removing the teacher exemption from fair employment legislation, and a bill to grant the Education Minister powers to dissolve the dysal General Teaching Council. That’s just within one department.And you could say, as MLAs reach the end of their five-year stint at Stormont, it’s election rush hour.In the space of a few hours, legislation on the free availability of period products, hospital car parking charges, domestic abuse safe leave from employment, the preservation of documents relating to historical institutions, safe access zones for abortion services and the fair employment of teachers were all speeding past in a blur.Sighs of relief for those who have worked to get their bills through for Royal Ascent, but maybe they made things a little harder for themselves than they needed to. Every Assembly mandate starts with the best intentions. The next one will be no dferent.While we should at least be grateful that important decisions are being made, it does all arrive with a little regret that the achievements were not being celebrated by cheering MLAs some time ago.Perhaps we should have elections more oftenwe want to get things done  Now there’s a worrying thought, but it is amazing what can be achieved when the spirit moves you.As elected MLAs reassemble, in whatever form of government the election brings come May, it would be refreshing to see the enthusiasm and the urgency to actually get things done that have been a hallmark of the final days of the current crop, bear fruit in the early days of a new administration.Last-minute winners can be more enjoyable and they do say all good things come to those who wait, but there title: qc to investigate possible union collusion in blacklisting
story: The blacklisting scandal dates back to  when a list of names were found in a file compiled by the Consulting Association  FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueThe blacklisting scandal dates back to  when a list of names were found in a file compiled by the Consulting Association By Alan Jones, PA Industrial CorrespondentMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailUnite has appointed a QC to investigate possible collusion by union officials in the blacklisting of construction workers.Nick Randall QC, and barrister John Carl Townsend, will begin their work next month.Unite said that over the past months, evidence gathering by Thompsons solicitors has continued, with many blacklisted construction workers and other witnesses interviewed.Unite general secretary Sharon Graham said: “Under my leadership Unite is committed to uncovering the truth about allegations of union collusion with blacklisting.Unite is committed to uncovering the truth about allegations of union collusion with blacklistingSharon Graham, Unite“The workers affected and their families deserve to know the truth and I hope that this QC-led independent inquiry will get to the bottom of what really happened.”Dave Smith, secretary of the Blacklist Support Group, commented: “Blacklisted workers have long demanded action that any investigation into union collusion in blacklisting must be completely independent from Unite and their own legal team.“The Blacklist Support Group applauds the appointment of such heavyweight and independently minded lawyers.“It is a clear indication that this investigation will not turn a blind eye to any evidence that exposes an unhealthy culture within Unite or its predecessor unions.The collusion investigation is neither mudslinging nor a whitewash - this is a robust independent process to uncover the truthDave Smith, Blacklist Support Group“The collusion investigation is neither mudslinging nor a whitewash – this is a robust independent process to uncover the truth.“The Blacklist Support Group repeats our call for anyone with evidence of union collusion in blacklisting to make contact with the investigation team.”The blacklisting scandal dates back to  when a list of names were found in a file compiled by the Consulting Association.Thousands of workers were on the list, often for being a union member or for raising safety issues.Many said they had dficulty finding work after being blacklisted by construction employers as a result of the list.
